In this episode, Jason Fung, nephrologist and best-selling author, shares his experiences utilizing an individualized approach to fasting to successfully treat thousands of overweight, metabolically ill, and diabetic patients, and why being a doctor who specializes in kidney disease gives him a unique insight into early indications of metabolic disease. We also have a great discussion on insulin resistance where Jason makes the case that we should actually think of hyperinsulinemia as the underlying problem. We also discuss the difference between time-restricted feeding, intermittent fasting, and dietary restriction (e.g., low-carb) and how they can be used to attack the root cause of T2D, metabolic syndrome, and obesity. We also have a fascinating discussion about the limitations of evidence-based medicine which leads to a conversation where we compare and contrast the scientific disciplines of medicine and biology to theoretical physics.

	Episode Details

In this episode, Jason Fung, nephrologist and best-selling author, shares his experiences utilizing an individualized approach to fasting to successfully treat thousands of overweight, metabolically ill, and diabetic patients, and why being a doctor who specializes in kidney disease gives him a unique insight into early indications of metabolic disease. We also have a great discussion on insulin resistance where Jason makes the case that we should actually think of hyperinsulinemia as the underlying problem. We also discuss the difference between time-restricted feeding, intermittent fasting, and dietary restriction (e.g., low-carb) and how they can be used to attack the root cause of T2D, metabolic syndrome, and obesity. We also have a fascinating discussion about the limitations of evidence-based medicine which leads to a conversation where we compare and contrast the scientific disciplines of medicine and biology to theoretical physics.      We discuss:  Comparing scientific disciplines: Medicine and biology versus physics [7:25]; The limitations of evidence-based medicine [12:30]; Early signs of metabolic disease: How specializing kidney disease gives Jason a unique insight into early indications of illness [20:50] Insulin resistance, hyperinsulinemia, and the overflow paradigm [29:30]; Why the common treatments for type 2 diabetes seem to make things worse [42:30]; How hyperinsulinemia (not insulin resistance) drives metabolic syndrome [53:15]; Insulin and weight gain, and using fasting to empty the cells of glucose [59:30]; The two step process of developing type 2 diabetes and how they are both manifestations of hyperinsulinemia [1:03:15]; NAFLD and hyperinsulinemia: A vicious cycle [1:08:30]; Are the features and symptoms of diabetes actually protective? [1:12:15]; Is obesity causing insulin resistance or is it the other way around? [1:17:30]; What role does inflammation play in obesity? [1:21:45]; CVD and cancer: Diseases of too much growth? [1:27:30]; How to reduce proliferation with rapamycin, nutrition, exercise, fasting, and manipulating hormones [1:32:45]; Getting patients to fast: How Jason and Peter utilize fasting in their practice, and how their approach differs [1:40:15]; Comparing bariatric surgery to fasting as a treatment for type 2 diabetes [1:48:00]; Why people think that fasting is bad for you [1:55:15]; Time-restricted feeding and intermittent fasting: Defining terms, and how Jason applies them in his practice [1:58:30]; A fasting case study: A diabetic patient with a non-healing foot ulcer [2:04:00]; Keys to a successful fast [2:12:45]; Muscle loss during fasting, and why Jason isn’t worried  [2:24:45]; Will fasting help a healthy person live longer? [2:31:30]; Does fasting cause gallstones? [2:38:45]; and More.  Learn more at www.PeterAttiaMD.com Connect with Peter on Facebook | Twitter | Instagram.

            Show NotesComparing scientific disciplines: Medicine and biology versus physics [7:25]
What makes Jason’s perspective unique

Peter says what distinguishes Jason from others who like to speak about the benefits (and risks) of fasting is that Jason is on the front lines treating patients
Jason agrees, and adds that he’s only interested in what works ⇒ “You can talk all you want about this and that, but if it doesn’t change management, then it doesn’t interest me particularly.”

Physics

Jason loves the approach to scientific progress in the realm of physics
He really looks up to Richard Feynman (as does Peter), Einstein, and Niels Bohr
“The way they do science is so much better than we do in medicine.”
In physics, if the theory doesn’t agree with experimental evidence, you have to throw out the theory
In medicine, bad theories tend to go round and round and round because they make sense, but nobody’s actually put them to the test
In the case of insulin resistance… “the way we think about insulin resistance is sort of totally wrong and that’s why we have the sort of mess that we have”


Biology vs. physics

Peter: “I’m generally suspect of people who have very, very strong points of view on things in biology or medicine who no longer interact with patients. Doesn’t mean that they’re wrong, but I’m generally suspect because of that.”
Biology is harder than physics…. it’s just a lot messier
Peter: “Every time I think I’ve really got it figured out, I’ll always meet a patient who proves me wrong.”

What Jason appreciates most about physics

Many great theories (e.g., Newton)
But then inevitably there are anomalies ⇒ “Anomalies are what drives sort of science forward because you have to come up with a better theory that explains the anomalies”
Then you come up with a better theory which may have wild predictions but it could supplant the existing theory (i.e. Niels Bohr’s quantum theory supplanted Einstein)
This doesn’t happen in medicine, says Jason… instead we have a super laborious process of evidence-based medicine

The limitations of evidence-based medicine [12:30]
Jason explains his frustrations…

In medicine, we have a super laborious process
We need evidence in order to move things forward
Whereas physics moves at “light speed” because it doesn’t demand the sort of evidence base
Evidence-based medicine is not a search for truth… it’s a search for consensus
This approach makes things move glacially

⇒ For example, fasting…

Five years ago, fasting was the dumbest thing you could do
But Jason treated hundreds and hundreds of patients, and the “results were amazing”

He still got major criticism:

“Where’s the evidence?!” 
“There’s no evidence, clearly this is bad!”



“That’s where everything just sort of bogs down. You can’t make intuitive leaps forward. That always bothers me a lot.”
Theorists vs. experimentalists

In physics, you can generally divide the field into the experimentalists and the theorists
That’s what I think allows the step-function changes in our understanding, says Peter
Einstein’s advances were theoretical, for example, and the experimental evidence to support these things came after 
And many times the big steps forward come on the basis of theoretical propositions
“We don’t really have that medicine and biology. We don’t have experimentalists and theorists.”

Where evidence-based medicine works
⇒ Best example of evidence-based medicine working: infectious disease

The treatment most infections is remarkable (e.g., HIV)

Infections are quite acute, very easy and binary to measure progression
The interventions are simple (i.e., take this medication/don’t take this medication)
You get the answer if it’s working really quickly (looking at T-cell count or amelioration)



⇒ The problem is that most things in medicine are much more complicated than this
“I think evidence-informed medicine is probably a better way to think about it.” says Peter
The risk of doing nothing

People are very quick to say, for instance, “Well, you don’t have the evidence to support fasting for a patient with Type II Diabetes.” 
But… what’s the risk of NOT doing something? 
*You must compare the risk of doing something (much more on the forefront of people’s minds) with the risk of NOT doing something (which people often forget to consider)*

⇒ For example, people with Type 2 diabetes

Risk of NOT doing anything:

Continue to get treated with more and more insulin to control blood glucose
It’s a virtual certainty that they will eventually have to go on dialysis
So the risk of doing nothing is huge compared to the risk of an intervention like fasting



Early signs of metabolic disease: How specializing kidney disease gives Jason a unique insight into early indications of illness [20:50]
Nephrology is a specialty of medicine that concerns itself with the kidneys: the study of normal kidney function and kidney disease, the preservation of kidney health, and the treatment of kidney disease, from diet and medication to renal replacement therapy (dialysis and kidney transplantation) [wikipedia.org]
Why did Jason choose nephrology?

He was drawn to internal medicine because generally it attracts people who “sort of like to think about things and try to solve puzzles”
And within nephrology, a subdivision of internal medicine, all you can do is think about things “because that’s all we could do”
Example, with kidney disease, there are two general treatments:

1 Prednisone
2 Dialysis


“The last time we had a drug that actually slowed down progression of kidney disease was the ACE inhibitors in the 80s.”
More recently, we have the SGLT2 inhibitors for diabetic kidney disease
“Before that, it’s like nothing. There wasn’t a lot to do, but there’s a lot to think about. That’s sort of what I liked about.”

Peter is impressed with 2 things about the kidney:
First, how intelligent it is

There was a very clever design in evolution 
The kidney pulls out everything and then dumps out the bad, and keeps what is good… because the probability that the good things are going to change is low, but the probability that you’ll see new bad things is high
Sock drawer analogy: It would be tempting to think that the kidney would operate like it’s going in your sock drawer to pull out just the right sock, but it doesn’t, it pulls out all of the socks and puts back the right ones.

Secondly, how small the kidney compared to how much it does

A very high fraction of our circulating blood volume passes through the kidney (about 20%)
This is part of the reason that the kidney is such an early warning indicator of disease either through high blood pressure or high glucose

The kidney as an early warning indicator of high blood pressure and high glucose

The eyes are generally the first place you can see disease
Second place is probably the kidneys by looking at urine (which is formed in the kidney)
About 20% of the entire blood circulation of the body passes through the kidney… and most of it passes through the glomerulus (“the functional unit of the kidney”)
The glomerulus, which you have about a million of these glomeruli in the body, are basically a big bag of blood vessels
If you have diseases of the blood vessel (heart disease and kidney disease are blood vessel diseases that generally show up later in life) … there are so many blood vessels in the kidney that can be affected and give you an early warning of worse disease to come

How we see disease in the urine

To look for signs of diabetes or high blood pressure, you measure the urine for what’s called the albumin to creatinine ratio
When you start to get increased urinary albumin excretion, that means there is damage to the vascular system
In contrast, looking at the liver…

It’s got a big vascular system, just like the kidney
But you can’t measure anything whereas the urine you can actually directly measure it



Correlation to heart disease
Increased urine albumin excretion has a very, very strong correlation to heart disease

Not because having albumin in the urine is so bad, but it tells you that there’s something bad going on in the blood vessels of the kidney
Which therefore tells you something bad is going on in the blood vessels of the body

In Peter’s practice…

He’s started to pay much closer attention to cystatin C, creatinine, along with microalbumin because he has begun to realize that the kidney, which often gets neglected, is one of the most important organs in terms of longevity

⇒ If you are in your 40s…

And you already have a glomerular filtration rate at 80% of what would be predicted, you have to fast forward a little bit and say, “Well, what’s that going to look like when you’re 80?”
The net implication for Peter has been a much greater focus on blood pressure, even just slightly elevated blood pressure
Many physicians (until recently) probably just weren’t thinking of as a significant enough problem
“There are a staggering amount of people walking around who on the surface, just based on the creatinine look pretty normal, but a slightly deeper look says, ‘No, actually, they’re not normal. They are compromised. It won’t be clinically relevant for 30 or 40 years, but that is going to be relevant.’”

There are no symptoms of kidney disease

The thing is that there are no symptoms
IgA Nephritis is the most common primary kidney disease in the world
But the patient will not know it
“They will have lost 95% of their kidney function by the time I see them just because they never knew they had a problem because they never checked it.” 
Fortunately, it’s so easy check in the urine, it’s non-invasive, and anybody can do it

Insulin resistance, hyperinsulinemia, and the overflow paradigm [29:30]
Explaining insulin resistance to a layperson

To start, Jason says the way he was taught insulin resistance in med school was wrong because it was only in terms of glucose

⇒ The wrong way to think about it…

Insulin is a hormone, and when insulin goes up, it allows glucose (through the GLUT4 receptor) to go from the blood into the cells
In the case of normal levels of insulin (unlike type 1 diabetes), and glucose can’t make it into the cells, we call it “insulin resistance” 
So if insulin is around, why can’t the glucose go into the cell? ⇒ It must be because of insulin resistance

⇒ This is the lock and key paradigm

Insulin is a hormone. It acts on the insulin receptor, which is on the cell surface. 
The insulin receptor is like a gate ⇒ There’s a door with a lock ⇒ Insulin is like the key so it opens the door ⇒ Therefore, the glucose can go from the blood into the cell for energy
When you look at insulin and insulin receptors and see there is nothing wrong with them, the common thinking is that there must be something that’s gumming up the system

And the gumming of the system is stopping the glucose from getting into the cell and so now the cell is facing an internal starvation
This internal starvation is why we give insulin to move the glucose into the cell
Jason says this thinking is almost completely incorrect

The central paradox of insulin resistance

Insulin has many, many different functions, and only one of which is letting glucose into the cell
And in many ways the body appears extremely sensitive to insulin in a person who has so-called insulin resistance

Examples…
⇒ In the liver…

Insulin is responsible for de novo lipogenesis
If there’s too much glucose after the glycogen is full, it’s going to turn it into triglycerides, or fat
So, de novo lipogenesis is working fine even in the face of insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes

“So, how can it be that you have a liver cell which can’t let in the glucose (so it’s resistant to the insulin) yet the other effect of insulin (de novo lipogenesis) is not only working fine, it’s actually going over time?”
⇒ What about the mitogenic effects of insulin? 

Insulin is a growth factor
So for example, with gestational age babies, we say that a woman has insulin resistance, yet insulin is actually doing what it’s supposed to do…. stimulating a lot of growth

⇒ Testosterone

Insulin has an effect on testosterone and PCOS
And again, it’s not just working fine, it’s working at a super high level

“In the liver, you have this central paradox where in the same tissue, to the same levels of insulin, you have both resistance and super sensitivity. That’s not really possible.”
⇒ Obesity…

A very common phenotype of insulin resistance is obesity (i.e., the accumulation of fat in a fat cell)
For a fat cell to get larger, it needs to incorporate triglyceride
To incorporate triglyceride requires insulin
So, on the one hand, this patient is insulin resistant… but looking the fat cell, it appears to be quite well insensitive to insulin

Hyperinsulinemia

The problem is not insulin resistance per se, the problem is hyperinsulinemia
Using insulin to push more and more glucose into the cells is a problem because the cell is already too full in a person with insulin resistance/T2D

⇒ The suitcase analogy

You are packing a suitcase
Your wife tells you to put more shirts in, so you do
But after she keeps asking you to put shirts in, you finally say “no”
Possible reasons you say “no”
The suitcase won’t open anymore so you can’t add shirts
It’s too full to add more
You simply decided to stop listening to her
But whether you are fully willing to add shirts, or if you are defiant to her request, the outcome looks the exact same… excess shirts outside the suitcase

⇒ In the case that you’re being stubborn and simply not listening to your wife… 

When we treat type 2 diabetes with big doses of exogenous insulin, we are essentially ramming the excess shirts (glucose) into the suitcase (cell) 

⇒ But if it’s an overflow paradigm, the implication is completely different…

Because the solution is to get rid of some of the stuff that’s in your suitcase
Putting more in is not the solution
The solution is to empty that cell of glucose… that’s the whole solution
But that is a totally different paradigm than what we’ve been taught… we use sulfonylureas and exogenous insulin trying to shove more glucose into this already filled cell

High insulin environment
Increasing insulin to deal with the excess glucose because of so-called “insulin resistance” actually supercharges the other effects of insulin on the body

It triggers the making of testosterone
You get PCOS
The growth effects of insulin which has huge implications for cancer
Example, breast cancer and colon cancer 

Very insulin sensitive
Much higher rates in type 2 diabetes and obesity
So, you’re getting the cancer-causing effects of the insulin, but yet you’re saying people are insulin resistant


So it makes sense that you have continued de novo lipogenesis even in the face of this so-called resistance, because you actually have too much insulin

Why the common treatments for type 2 diabetes seem to make things worse [42:30]

The majority of drugs to treat T2D aren’t actually aimed at decreasing glucose, it’s more about increasing insulin, such as…

Sulfonylureas
Exogenous insulin
DPP-4 inhibitors

Continuing the suitcase analogy…

These drugs are similar to your wife screaming at you to put more shirts in
At first, you can do it, but as you keep doing that, the problem just keeps getting worse and worse
At first it’s a little full, and then it’s a lot too full

Progressively worse

If you watch a patient with T2D diabetes, you can see his condition just get progressively worse over time even when on these medications
The treatment was completely incorrect
We kept putting more shirts in when we should’ve been taking shirts out
We kept putting more glucose into the liver, which is what insulin does, instead of taking all that glucose out of the liver

Why tight control of glucose with insulin doesn’t work long term

Trials like ACCORD, ADVANCE, and VADT all failed because they were working on this incorrect paradigm of insulin resistance (lock and key paradigm) 
Macrovascular vs. microvascular disease

When diabetes trials are using glycemia as their end point (meaning how low can you get the hemoglobin A1c/how “tightly” can you control the glucose) the patients will see benefits in microvascular problems
But the opposite is not true
By taking someone’s average glucose from 200 down to 150, that would be considered a huge win in a diabetes trial (and that benefit might show up in their kidneys)
But if you had to double the amount of insulin you gave them to do that, it turns out that at the macrovascular level (e.g., heart and brain) they don’t get any better, they get worse

This indicates that hyperinsulinemia itself is problematic





See Peter’s discussion with Jake Kushner for more
It’s about whole-body glucose, not just blood glucose

It’s not the blood glucose per se, it’s the whole-body glucose, says Jason
If you take the glucose that’s in the blood and simply shove it into the liver, have you done anything good for this patient? ⇒ The answer is no, because you’re just covering up the problem
It’s the whole-body glucose moving the glucose from one compartment of the body, which is the blood, to another compartment, which is the liver

SGLT2 inhibitors

The SGLT2s are a new class of drug which blocks the receptor on the kidneys where you’re actually absorbing the glucose, and you actually pee out the sugar

You do get some side effects: Urine infections, yeast infections, and for some reason, you get ketoacidosis, too



If you look at the trials, they’re actually quite consistent that you get a huge protective effects against kidney disease…

Reduce the risk of kidney disease by about 25%
And reduce the risk of heart disease
Never seen before in any class of antidiabetic drug
The reason it’s working is because it’s getting rid of the glucose as opposed to simply moving it around…“We’re emptying out that suitcase”
The amount of lowering of blood sugar was super unimpressive in all of these trials
Every single one of these trials shows organ protection with almost no benefit to your blood sugar (A1c would only drop 0.3 or 0.4) 
It was terrible for the blood sugar, but the end points were incredible

Why? ⇒ You’re actually treating the underlying problem of too much whole-body glucose as opposed to too much glucose in the blood (two totally different problems)



How hyperinsulinemia (not insulin resistance) drives metabolic syndrome [53:15]
Exercise

Peter points out that exercise increases a reservoir for glucose uptake, the muscle
The more one exercises, the more he/she could put away glucose into a muscle as glycogen

⇒ What magnitude of benefit does exercise have on T2D?

There is a benefit, for sure
But it is much less efficient than attacking the diet
The liver is really the key to type 2 diabetes, and you can’t exercise the liver

Metabolic syndrome and insulin
Metabolic syndrome which is a constellation of five things:

Increased blood glucose
Abdominal obesity
High triglycerides
Low HDL
High blood pressure

How does hyperinsulinemia play a role in metabolic syndrome?

The liver is now busy exporting out tons and tons of the fat
The liver has too much glucose because of too much insulin so the liver is jam-packed
It wants to get rid of all this extra fat so it’s putting out tons of triglycerides (you get hypertriglyceridemia)
And as triglycerides go up, HDL goes down
As you’re exporting out all of this fat, this fat goes into all kinds of places where it’s not supposed to go (the pancreas, the omentum fat, etc.) and you get abdominal obesity 
And it’s not because of dietary fat, because dietary fat doesn’t go into the liver
Dietary fat goes into the chylomicrons, which goes into the blood vessels, which is taken out by the adipocytes
The belly fat is because the liver is pouring out all this new fat that gets taken up in all the organs around it
Insulin also has an effect on blood pressure because insulin causes reabsorption of sodium at the site of the proximal tubule
The whole syndrome is not a syndrome of insulin resistance… It’s a syndrome of hyperinsulinemia

If the problem is hyperinsulinemia, then the solution is completely obvious

Insulin is high… so we need to lower it
It’s no different than if your thyroid is too high, you want to lower it
In T2D, we know that insulin levels are high… so why did we think it would get better by giving more insulin? ⇒  We totally misunderstand the problem

Easier to treat “hypo” and “hyper”

With hormones, it tends to be easier to treat a case of too little (hypo) and too much (hypo) of a particular hormone

   ⇒ Example, it’s much easier to treat low cortisol than to get a super stressed person with high cortisol to bring it down (there’s no pill to lower cortisol)

With type 1 diabetes, just give more insulin
But with T2D, which is too much insulin, there was no drug (now there is SGLT2)… and we would give more insulin (“it’s so ridiculous”)

Insulin and weight gain, and using fasting to empty the cells of glucose [59:30]

Studies (like the DCCT) show that insulin causes weight gain 
People gained weight and eventually became hyperinsulinemic
Even T1D patients became hyperinsulinemic…
You start out taking 15 units a day when you’re a kid
And then by the time you’re 45, you’re taking like 60 units a day
Why? You developed insulin resistance, and yet you had no insulin in your body in the first place 20 years ago
We thought that giving more insulin was good, but we didn’t realize that, hey, too much insulin is just as bad as too little insulin (or worse in this case)

The negative feedback loop

We actually know a lot about how this sort of overflow paradigm works, biochemically
It’s called the TCA cycle

“We worked out the whole biochemistry of how this overflow paradigm is supposed to work. We actually teach high school students that, ‘Hey, if you’re feeding in way too much of [insulin] into the TCA cycle, there’s a negative feedback loop.’”

ATP is going to block glycolysis which is going to block that glucose so you don’t overload the system
So now glucose can’t go in anymore
In other words, hyperinsulinemia, which is actually too much glucose, too much insulin, is going to feed back and not let the glucose into the cell which is why the glucose stays outside (in the blood), and you have this so-called insulin resistance
But the key is to empty out the cell of glucose
And how are you going to do that? ⇒ Low carbohydrate diets and intermittent fasting, says Jason

Fasting to empty the cells of glucose
“There is no more potent way to lower insulin than to fast.” —Peter Attia

Many people spend time arguing about whether low-fat or low-carb diets work best to lower insulin… but they seem to forget the infinitely more potent tool: eating nothing at all

By eating nothing you are going to force your body to start using another fuel, and the first place it’s going to pull it out of is this fatty liver (which, by the way, is causing a ton of cirrhosis and T2D because it’s actually part of the same problem)

The two step process of developing type 2 diabetes and how they are both manifestations of hyperinsulinemia [1:03:15] 
The two-step process of developing type 2 diabetes

First is insulin resistance (or said a better way: hyperinsulinemia)
Next, Pancreas atrophies after spending so much effort to produce more and more insulin and it finally fails (beta-cell failure)
After the beta-cell failure is when the blood glucose go way up
Process takes about 10 years
So the rising insulin resistance is met with hyperinsulinemia, which keeps the blood glucose normal, and it keeps it normal for a long time at the expense of hyperinsulinemia.

The current mainstream thinking is that insulin resistance, and beta-cell failure are totally separate

Muscle loss during fasting, and why Jason isn’t worried  [2:24:45]
Does Jason do anything specific to minimize muscle loss when his patients are fasting?

Nothing specifically, says Jason
But he’s generally treating a very sick population (i.e., not bodybuilders) who urgently need to lose weight and correct things

No excess skin after radical weight loss

One of the things that’s very unusual about fasting for weight loss as opposed to weight loss for other things is that we don’t see the excess, flabby skin problems
Why?

Skin is made of protein and connective tissue
When you do the intermittent fasting, you go through a period where you have gluconeogenesis and you’re breaking down protein



Skin flaps from calorie restriction

With massive weight loss from chronic calorie restriction, you are much more likely to see the large flaps of excess skin left over
But your body should get rid of it… so why doesn’t your body get rid of it?
It’s because you never went through this period of gluconeogenesis, where you actually are breaking down protein

Protein loss or muscle loss?

Jason says that the protein loss is often confused and called muscle loss

It makes no sense that the body should store food energy as glycogen and body fat, but the minute you need to use it, you start burning muscle

⇒ Analogy: “It’s like storing firewood for the winter. Then, as soon as you need to use it, you chop up your sofa and throw it in the fire. . . I don’t think our bodies are that stupid.” 
Gluconeogenesis

There’s a period, which is fairly limited, during the fast thing where you have gluconeogenesis
Then you can see fat oxidation goes way up
Here’s a 1969 study by George Cahill

⇒ Paper by Frank Nuttall

He tried to estimate how much excess protein
He found that somebody who is overweight has 20 to 50% more protein than a regular person
That excess protein is in the form of skin, muscle, connective tissue, blood vessels
“There’s all kinds of extra protein that goes along with being overweight and that all needs to go.”

Will fasting help a healthy person live longer? [2:31:30]
Can a heathy person (meaning non-obese, insulin-sensitive, non hyperinsulinemic person) benefit from periodic fasting in terms of reducing the odds of chronic disease down the line?

“Absolutely, yes.”
If you use fasting to drop your insulin levels every so often, you’re going to lower your chance of getting diseases of hyperinsulinemia (heart disease, stroke, cancer, Alzheimer’s disease, type two diabetes, obesity)

What about something like quarterly prolonged fasting (5+ days) to increase longevity?

Jason says if you take the perspective of evidence-based medicine, you might say that there is no evidence it can improve longevity/ward off chronic disease
However… what is the risk/reward ratio?

In terms of risk, Jason says it’s “just about zero”
In terms of reward, it could be potentially massive


So the real question is… why wouldn’t you do it?

⇒ For example, let’s say you have rheumatoid arthritis

If the Valter Longo’s FMD says it can help “reset” your immune system and improve your autoimmune disease… why wouldn’t you try it?
“We know what prednisone does to people, so why wouldn’t I do seven days of fasting? The risk of that is zero. Say I don’t get any benefit from that, then I don’t have to do it ever again. Gallstones and the low fat diet

The problem is that people who follow a low fat diet seem to run into issues
Your gallbladder uses bile to emulsify fats
Therefore when there’s not fat in your diet the bile just sits around with all this stuff and you get sludge
Then, you start eating a higher fat diet and you are then squeezing it out and you’re getting stones

“I don’t see it clinically as a problem. I think what caused a lot of the problems was probably the lower fat diet because you’re simply not getting the flow. The intrahepatic flow. . . we think we’re so much smarter than our body, which has survived for millions of years. We’re going to eat zero fat and just have all this sludge just sit in the gallbladder because you never took it out. How does that make sense? To me, it makes no sense.”
